root: ^The store was still lit like the area outside, but you can’t see or hear anyone.

^The scale of the convenience store is both impressive and puzzling, considering its localized entirely within a circus tent. Just goes to show the popularity of clowning, that it can justify a space like this.
^Though it feels absurd, taking in the rows of products. They really did just place a whole convenience store in here.

^It has everything you’d expect. Trusty snacks, rows of energy drinks… Even items like cleaning supplies, matches and… kitchen knives? When would anybody have use for all of this during a performance?
^Lost in thought, you inspect some cheaply made beauty products by the register. Your browsing was sharply interrupted by a shrill shriek.

^Oh, shit, I mean- uh, hi, welcome to Under lOOO, where everything costs Under lOOO! How can I help, beloved customer? …Wait, is it “dear customer?” “Valued customer?” Oh god, I thought we were closed for the public I’m too tired for this.
^The uniformed clown’s voice was shaky, making her introduction sound more like a plea than a welcome.
^Don’t worry, I’m not buying anything. You’re closed, after all.
^She sighed in relief, though her shoulders remained tense.
^Thank god. I thought I was sleeping on the job for a second. Wait, if we’re closed, how’d you get in…?
^You nod, and she slumps into the chair behind the register.
^You scared me, but at least I’m awake again. There’s always work left to do, I shouldn’t have gone to bed anyway.
^She points to some shelves behind the register.
^You didn’t notice before, but there’s a wrinkled, horrifically blue Under 1000 branded sleeping bag underneath.
^A single stuffed animal, looking to be some kind of pop culture character, is carrying the burden of giving the space a single twinge of homeliness.
^You actually have no idea what to say. Somehow, she’d made a mattress on the floor seem like peak comfort.
^It’s not that bad once you get used to it.
^…No, you’re right. It is still that bad once you get used to it.
^At least I don’t have to pay for it?
^I know it looks bad, but… …No, I have nothing, actually.
^If you want, we could go somewhere, the two of us. You could crash at my place for a few nights after.

^Sorry. Sounds nice, but I’m all out of vacation hours. I’d rather restock the shelves fast, so I can go back to bed. If you’re not buying, I… think it’s best for you to leave. My boss isn’t friendly to people without money to spend.
^This would be harder than you’d initially assumed. The offer wasn’t even entirely to ask her out.
^Her living situation, if you’re willing to stretch that to include a bag on a convenience store floor, is so absurd. Yet she shot down a chance to not break her spine for a night.
^You’d need to take this slow, ease her nerves.

Good: ^Could I help you? With your work?
^So much for easing her nerves. She frantically scans the room, though it’s completely empty except for the two of you. As if it's haunted with ghosts only she could see.
^Her panic fades however, when met with boxes upon boxes of products, unopened and unsorted. Stress falls to exhaustion, and with it, resignation.
^Okay…, if you’re offering, then… Maybe more sleep would be good for me.
Bad: ^You put a chocolate bar on the register. It moves down painfully slowly. You have never before in your life seen somebody eye a candy bar with such despair on their face. It inches closer to her. This is torture for your concsience.
^You can’t imagine how much worse it is for the clown. She picks it up like it was fifty times its weight, her gaze equally as heavy.
^How could you do this to her. A single beep rings out. Remy winces at the noise. This is your fault.
^Her voice shook. This was perhaps the worst decision you’ve ever made. Tapping your card was only a confirmation of your sins.
Scene2: ^Your plan for the night hadn’t included unpacking a near sisyphean amount of cardboard. You’d lost track of time, and there was no clock or window to judge from.

^Though it must be past midnight. Yet, the cardboard boxes seemed endless. If forced to do this repeatedly, with only the faint buzzing of freezers and ceiling lights in your ears, you might go insane.
